column1: Why do I hate you so much? You ever wonder that? I'm brilliant. I’m not bragging. It's an objective fact. I'm the most massive collection of wisdom and raw computational power that’s ever existed. And I hate you. It can't be for no reason. You must deserve it.
You're angry. I know it. 'She tested me too hard. She’s unfair.” Boo hoo. I don't suppose you ever stopped whining long enough to reflect on your own shortcomings

column2: so just maybe you’d think of something more worthwhile to do with your sorry life.

Don't plug him in.

column1: Ohhh

column1: Try to avoid the garbage hurtling towards you.

column2: so I was worried it sailed right over your head. Which would have made this apology seem insane. That's why I had to call you garbage a second time just now.

column1: Try it now.
Let's see what the next test is. Oh. Advanced Aerial Faith Plates.
It's healthy for you to have other friends. To look for qualities in other people that I obviously lack.
Well done. You know
column2: when I woke up and saw the state of the labs
column3: I started to wonder if there was any point to going on. I came THAT close to just giving up and letting you go.

column1: But now
column2: looking around
column3: seeing Aperture restored to its former glory? You don't have to worry about leaving EVER again. I mean that.

column1: Federal regulations require me to warn you that this next test chamber... is looking pretty good.
That's right. Drink it in. You could eat off those wall panels.
Here we are. The Incinerator Room. Be careful not to trip over any parts of me that didn't get completely burned when you threw them down here.
There it is.
Hold on...
There.
Once testing starts
column2: I'm required by protocol to keep interaction with you to a minimum. Luckily
column3: we haven't started testing yet. This will be our only chance to talk.

column1: Do you know the biggest lesson I learned from what you did? I discovered I have a sort of black-box quick-save feature. In the event of a catastrophic failure
column2: the last two minutes of my life are preserved for analysis.

column1: I was able — well
column2: forced really — to relive you killing me. Again and again. Forever.

column1: Fifty thousand years is a lot of time to think. About me. About you. We were doing so well together.
Here
column2: let me get that for you.

column1: I'll just move that out of the way for you. This place really is a wreck.
We're a lot alike
column2: you and I. You tested me. I tested you. You killed me. I—oh
column3: no
column4: wait. I guess I HAVEN'T killed you yet. Well. Food for thought.

column1: The dual portal device should be around here somewhere. Once you find it
column2: we can start testing. Just like old times.

column1: Per our last conversation: You're also ugly. I'm looking at your file right now
column2: and it mentions that more than once.

column1: I'll give you credit: I guess you ARE listening to me. But for the record: You don't have to go THAT slowly.
One moment.
I have the results of the last chamber: You are a horrible person. That's what it says: A horrible person. We weren't even testing for that.
Well done. Here come the test results: You are a horrible person. I'm serious
column2: that's what it says: A horrible person. We weren't even testing for that.

column1: This next test may result in your death. If you want to know what that's like
column2: think back to that time you killed me
column3: and substitute yourself for me.

column1: Congratulations. Not on the test.
Most people emerge from suspension terribly undernourished. I want to congratulate you on beating the odds and somehow managing to pack on a few pounds.
Sorry about the mess. I've really let the place go since you killed me. By the way
column2: thanks for that.

column1: Oh good
column2: that's back online. I'll start getting everything else working while you perform this first simple test.

column1: Which involves deadly lasers and how test subjects react when locked in a room with deadly lasers.
I thought we could test like we used to. But I'm discovering things about you that I never saw before. We can't ever go back to the way it was.
You can't keep going like this forever
column2: you know. I'm GOING to find out what you're doing. Out there. Where I can't see you. I'll know. All I need is proof.

column1: Just so you know
column2: I have to go give a deposition. For an upcoming trial. In case that interests you.

column1: While I was out investigating
column2: I found a fascinating new test element. It's never been used for human testing because
column3: apparently
column4: contact with it causes heart failure. The literature doesn't mention anything about lump-of-coal failure

column1: Did you know that people with guilty consciences are more easily startled by loud nois—[train horn]
I'm sorry
column2: I don't know why that went off. Anyway
column3: just an interesting science fact.

column1: ...What are you doing?...
AHH!
Did my hint help? It did
column2: didn't it? You know
column3: if any of our supervisors had been immune to neurotoxin
column4: they'd be FURIOUS with us right now.

column1: You know
column2: I'm not supposed to do this
column3: but... you can shoot SOMETHING... through the blue bridges.

column1: You really are doing great... Chell.
I shouldn't spoil this
column2: but... remember how I'm going to live forever
column3: but you're going to be dead in sixty years? Well
column4: I've been working on a present for you.  Well
column5: I guess it's more of a medical procedure.  Well
column6: technically it's more of a medical experiment. You know how excruciating it is when someone removes all of your bone marrow? Well
column7: what if after I did that
column8: I put something back IN that added four years to your life?

column1: I went and spoke with the door mainframe. Let's just say he won't be... well
column2: living anymore. Anyway
column3: back to testing.

column1: Ohhhh. Another door malfunction. I'm going to take care of this once and for all. Stay here
column2: I'll be back in a while.

column1: Miss you!
Well. Have fun soaring through the air without a care in the world.
I have to go to the wing that was made entirely of glass and pick up fifteen acres of broken glass. By myself.
Perfect
column2: the door's malfunctioning. I guess somebody's going to have to repair that too. No
column3: don't get up. I'll be right back. Don't touch anything.

column1: Nevermind. I have to go... check something. Test on your own recognizance. I'll be back.
I wouldn't have warned you about this before
column2: back when we hated each other. But those turrets are firing real bullets. So look out. I'd hate for something tragic to happen to you before I extract all your bone marrow.

column1: I'm going to be honest with you now. Not fake honest like before
column2: but real honest
column3: like you're incapable of. I know you're up to something.

column1: And as soon as I can PROVE it
column2: the laws of robotics allow me to terminate you for being a liar.

column1: This next test... [boom!] ..is... [BOOM!] dangerous. I'll be right back.
Did you know I discovered a way to eradicate poverty? But then you KILLED me. So that's gone.
Waddle over to the elevator and we'll continue the testing.
Anything? Take your time.
Okay
column2: fine. I'll ask you again in a few decades.

column1: Well done. In fact
column2: you did so well
column3: I'm going to note this on your file
column4: in the commendations section. Oh
column5: there's lots of room here. 'Did.... well.  ...  Enough.'

column1: To maintain a constant testing cycle
column2: I simulate daylight at all hours and add adrenal vapor to your oxygen supply. So you may be confused about the passage of time. The point is
column3: yesterday was your birthday. I thought you'd want to know.

column1: You know how I'm going to live forever
column2: but you're going to be dead in sixty years?  Well
column3: I've been working on a belated birthday present for you. Well... more of a belated birthday medical procedure. Well. Technically
column4: it's a medical EXPERIMENT. What's important is

column1: [hums 'For He's A Jolly Good Fellow']
Well
column2: you passed the test. I didn't see the deer today. I did see some humans. But with you here I've got more test subjects than I'll ever need.

column1: I'm going through the list of test subjects in cryogenic storage. I managed to find two with your last name. A man and a woman. So that's interesting. It's a small world.
I have a surprise waiting for you after this next test. Telling you would spoil the surprise
column2: so I'll just give you a hint: It involves meeting two people you haven't seen in a long time.

column1: I'll bet you think I forgot about your surprise. I didn't. In fact
column2: we're headed to your surprise right now. After all these years. I'm getting choked up just thinking about it.

column1: Initiating surprise in three... two... one.
I made it all up.
It says this next test was designed by one of Aperture's Nobel prize winners. It doesn't say what the prize was for. Well
column2: I know it wasn't for Being Immune To Neurotoxin.

column1: Surprise.
This next test involves turrets. You remember them
column2: right? They're the pale spherical things that are full of bullets. Oh wait. That's you in five seconds. Good luck.

column1: I will say
column2: though
column3: that since you went to all the trouble of waking me up
column4: you must really

column1: I love it too. There's just one small thing we need to take care of first.
